study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of flaxseed oil on cognitive and motor impairments in rats with hyperammonemia, focusing on memory, motor function, and neuronal morphology.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil prevented cognitive and motor impairments in hyperammonemic rats, maintained normal neuronal morphology in the prefrontal cortex, and showed no adverse effects compared to an ammonium-rich diet.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with hyperammonemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of flaxseed supplementation on adipokine concentrations, specifically leptin and adiponectin, through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced leptin levels but had no considerable effect on adiponectin concentrations. The study highlights the need for further well-designed trials to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Not specified (meta-analysis of 13 RCTs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of flaxseed oil (FLO) with and without optimized quercetin (Q) on broiler chickens' performance and oxidative stress biomarkers.
results_summary: The FLO diet did not affect final performance parameters compared to rapeseed oil (RO), but increased liver malondialdehyde (MDA) content and catalase (CAT) activity. Optimized Q showed potential to mitigate negative effects of FLO diets.
population_specificity: One-day-old Ross 308 broiler chicken males (n=96).
effective_dosage: Not specified (optimized quercetin concentration based on peroxidability of oils).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of flaxseed nano-emulsion (NEFO) with other nano-emulsion oils (olive and grapeseed) on semen quality, freezability, and oxidative damage in buffalo sperm.
results_summary: Flaxseed nano-emulsion (NEFO) improved sperm membrane integrity, vitality, and reduced oxidative damage markers (MDA, NO) compared to the control, though it was less effective than grapeseed nano-emulsion (NEGSO). NEFO also showed lower caspase 3 levels and attenuated ultrastructural sperm damage.
population_specificity: Buffalo bull semen samples.
effective_dosage: 3.5% nano-emulsion flaxseed oil (NEFO) in freezing extender.
study_duration: Not specified (post-thaw evaluation at 37°C for 30s and incubation for 2h).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether partially replacing soybean meal with flaxseed and lupins in dairy cow diets affects milk production, fertility traits, and metabolic health.
results_summary: The study found no negative effects on milk yield or composition, improved fertility in multiparous cows (earlier estrus and conception), and reduced NEFA concentrations and acute phase protein levels in the treatment group.
population_specificity: Dairy cows (330 animals, divided into treated and control groups).
effective_dosage: 50% substitution of soybean meal with an equal mixture of flaxseed and lupins.
study_duration: 81 days (25 days prepartum and 56 days postpartum).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of flaxseed and olive oil consumption on endothelial function, inflammatory factors, and lipid profile in patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: Flaxseed and olive oil significantly improved endothelial function (FMD%), reduced plasma IL-6, TNF-α, MCP-1, total cholesterol, and showed a trend toward reducing hs-CRP and non-HDL cholesterol, though other indices remained unchanged.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of seed cycling, including flaxseed, in improving hormonal disturbances and FSH/LH levels in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Seed cycling combined with a portion-controlled diet reduced FSH levels by 1.2%-2.5% and LH levels by 1.5%-2% in women with PCOS, showing significant hormonal improvement compared to the control group.
population_specificity: 90 women with PCOS, aged 15-40 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (seed cycling included, but exact flaxseed dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of flaxseed, alone and in combination with atorvastatin, on NAFLD-related indicators in rats fed a fat/fructose-enriched diet.
results_summary: Flaxseed significantly reduced triglycerides, cholesterol, liver enzymes (AST, ALT, GGT), and fasting blood sugar levels in NAFLD-induced rats. It also showed a notable impact on LDL levels and LDL/HDL ratio.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with NAFLD induced by a fat/fructose-enriched diet and carbon tetrachloride.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how microwave treatment affects the physicochemical stability and gastrointestinal digestion of oil bodies in flaxseed milk.
results_summary: Microwave treatment slightly reduced the physical stability of flaxseed milk but prevented phase separation during storage. It altered the oil body interface, leading to earlier lipolysis during digestion and enhanced absorption of fatty acids, including conversion to docosapentaenoic and docosahexaenoic acids.
population_specificity: Rats (enterocytes studied)
effective_dosage: Flaxseed moisture adjusted to 30-35 wt%, microwave exposure (0-5 min, 700 W)
study_duration: 21 days of storage at 4°C (intervention duration not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence supporting the health benefits of dietary flaxseed, identify its mechanisms of action, and discuss practical aspects of its inclusion in the diet.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed supplementation has beneficial effects on cardiovascular diseases, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, breast cancer, bone strength, menopause, diabetes, and wound healing, likely due to its omega-3 fatty acid content.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals and those with disease conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed oil and flaxseed grain on the intestinal microbiota and blood fatty acid profiles in Albas cashmere goats.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil and grain reduced microbial diversity in the small intestine and cecum/colon, with flaxseed grain being more effective in promoting intestinal health and c18:3n3 absorption. The LNO group showed increased Proteobacteria, while the HLS group had higher Actinobacteria.
population_specificity: Albas cashmere goats (60 kid goats).
effective_dosage: Not specified (basal diet with added flaxseed oil or heated flaxseed grain).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flaxseed powder (FLA) improves host metabolism by modulating gut bacteria and bile acid metabolism in mice fed a high-fat diet.
results_summary: FLA significantly reduced body weight, body fat content, serum TG, LDL-C, and TNF-α levels, improved liver steatosis, and regulated gut flora disturbance and bile acid metabolism.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed oil (FSO) as a feed additive on growth performance, oxidative stress, immunity, and disease resistance in rainbow trout.
results_summary: FSO supplementation significantly improved growth performance, enhanced immune response, and reduced oxidative damage in rainbow trout. Fish fed FSO showed higher resistance to Y. ruckeri but similar survival rates against A. hydrophila compared to controls.
population_specificity: Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) with a mean weight of 25.66 ± 1.33 g.
effective_dosage: 0.5%, 1%, and 1.5% FSO ad libitum twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight a potential association between flaxseed consumption (a phytoestrogen source) and hypercoagulable states contributing to acute portal vein thrombosis (PVT) in a patient on testosterone replacement therapy (TRT).
results_summary: The study reported a case where flaxseed consumption, alongside TRT and recent abdominal surgery, may have contributed to a hypercoagulable state leading to acute PVT. It emphasized awareness of potential contributors to hypercoagulability.
population_specificity: A 50-year-old male with no history of cirrhosis or hypercoagulable disorders, on TRT and consuming flaxseed.
interactions: Possible interaction with testosterone replacement therapy (TRT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ground flaxseed supplementation on adiponectin, resistin, and visfatin concentrations in patients with ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced resistin and visfatin levels while increasing adiponectin levels in UC patients after 12 weeks. The results were statistically significant and clinically relevant.
population_specificity: 64 patients (36 men, 28 women) with ulcerative colitis, mean age 31.12±9.67.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary flaxseed oil and ascorbic acid could mitigate seasonal variations in semen quality, testosterone levels, and scrotal size in South African indigenous rams.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed oil and ascorbic acid supplementation improved progressive motility and testosterone levels, reversing seasonal effects. Significant improvements were observed with combined FLAX + ASCA supplementation across seasons.
population_specificity: South African indigenous rams (n=22)
study_duration: 12 months (with semen collection after 60 days of supplementation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the chemical composition of flaxseed and its effects on female reproductive health, including ovarian function, hormonal regulation, and potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed and its bioactive molecules influence ovarian growth, follicle development, reproductive cycles, and hormonal regulation, potentially benefiting reproductive efficiency and treating conditions like polycystic ovarian syndrome and ovarian cancer. These effects are mediated through metabolic and intracellular signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Female reproductive system (general review, not specific to humans or animals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the structural properties and anti-obesity effects of insoluble and soluble dietary fibers extracted from flaxseed cake in diet-induced obese mice.
results_summary: Supplementation with flaxseed soluble dietary fiber (FSDF) alone or combined with insoluble dietary fiber (FIDF) reduced fat accumulation, improved serum lipid profiles, increased basal metabolism, and enhanced gut microbiota. FIDF alone improved liver lipid profiles, raised basal metabolism, and increased short-chain fatty acid levels in the gut.
population_specificity: Male diet-induced obese mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of alpha-linolenic acid from flaxseed oil on various cognitive functions in healthy older adults.
results_summary: Daily consumption of flaxseed oil containing 2.2 g alpha-linolenic acid significantly improved verbal fluency, a measure of executive function, but did not significantly affect other cognitive functions.
population_specificity: Healthy older adults aged 65 to 80 years without cognitive impairment or depression.
effective_dosage: 3.7 g/day of flaxseed oil (containing 2.2 g alpha-linolenic acid).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory and antioxidant effects of flaxseed oil, alone and in combination with olive oil, on inflammatory markers and wound healing in burn patients.
results_summary: The combination of flaxseed and olive oil (OF) showed the greatest reduction in inflammatory markers (hs-CRP and ferritin) and significant improvement in wound healing by the second and third weeks compared to the control group. Flaxseed oil alone did not show significant early wound healing effects but contributed to positive outcomes when combined with olive oil.
population_specificity: Burn patients with a total burn surface area (TBSA) of 20-50%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how pH-shifting affects the textural and microstructural properties of mung bean starch-flaxseed protein composite gels.
results_summary: pH 12-shifting improved water-holding capacity, storage modulus, and gel strength, while pH 2-shifting resulted in looser gel networks with lower water-holding capacity and hardness due to protein denaturation and starch degradation. The findings suggest pH-shifting can modify gel properties by altering protein secondary structures and hydrogen bonding.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on composite gels)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effect of flaxseed lignans on isoproterenol-induced cardiac hypertrophy, focusing on structural and functional cardiac alterations.
results_summary: Flaxseed lignans significantly improved cardiac hypertrophy by reducing heart weight, lowering CK-MB and malondialdehyde levels, enhancing antioxidant capacity, and preventing collagen deposition and tissue damage. The results suggest lignans may regulate myocardial remodeling and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Animal model (rats with induced cardiac hypertrophy)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of flaxseed oil supplementation combined with physical exercise on hippocampal plasticity and behavioral aspects in Wistar rats.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed oil supplementation combined with exercise altered GFAP expression in hippocampal astrocytes and modulated memory and anxiety behaviors. The combination showed potential benefits for neuroprotection and neuroplasticity.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of heat treatment and flaxseed gum (FG) on the particle characteristics, physical properties, and stability of commercial spray-dried soy protein isolate (SPI).
results_summary: Heating SPI at 100°C reduced particle size, hydrophobicity, and viscosity while increasing stability, whereas 75°C heating increased hydrophobicity and viscosity but decreased stability. FG addition increased particle size, zeta potential, and hydrophobicity but reduced viscosity at low concentrations, improving stability below 0.2% FG.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on SPI dispersions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of flaxseed supplementation on blood pressure through a meta-analysis of existing clinical trials.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced both systolic and diastolic blood pressure, with greater effects observed in trials lasting over 20 weeks, using ≥30 g/day of flaxseed, in overweight individuals (BMI 25-30 kg/m²), and in hypertensive patients. The findings support flaxseed as an effective supplement for blood pressure management alongside routine medications.
population_specificity: 2,427 participants across 33 trials, including individuals with varying BMI and hypertensive patients.
study_duration: Trials with intervention durations >20 weeks showed greater effects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed oil supplementation on body weight, reproductive parameters, hormonal profiles, oxidative stress markers, and semen quality in Teressa goat bucks during different seasons.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil supplementation improved body weight, scrotal and testicular measurements, hormone levels (FSH, LH, testosterone, TSH, T3, T4), antioxidant capacity, libido, and semen quality while reducing cortisol, prolactin, and oxidative stress markers, particularly during the rainy season.
population_specificity: Male Teressa goats (3-4 years old) in Andaman and Nicobar Islands, India.
effective_dosage: 25 mL per day, orally drenched before feeding.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the bioavailability of flaxseed lignans, factors affecting it, and strategies to improve their release and delivery for health benefits.
results_summary: The study highlights that flaxseed lignans have multiple health benefits but suffer from poor bioavailability. Various food design strategies can enhance their release and bioavailability, though absorption issues like variability in pharmacokinetics remain.
population_specificity: Not specified (review study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-melanogenesis effects of LOMIX and individual Linosorbs (LO) from flaxseed oil, focusing on their potential to inhibit melanin synthesis in melanoma cell lines.
results_summary: LOMIX and LO significantly suppressed melanin secretion and synthesis in a dose-dependent manner, with up to 95% inhibition. LO1 and LO2 specifically reduced melanin synthesis by 90% without toxicity and downregulated key melanogenesis-related genes and signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Mouse melanoma cell lines (B16F10).
effective_dosage: LOMIX (50 and 100 μg/mL), LO (6.25-50 μM), LO1 and LO2 (12.5 and 25 μM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the bioactive properties of flaxseed orbitides (LOs), particularly their potential to suppress immunity, induce apoptosis in cancer cells, and modulate gene expression.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed orbitides (LOs) suppressed immunity, induced apoptosis in human epithelial cancer cells (Calu-3), and modulated regulatory genes. LOs also promoted apoptosis and induced heat shock proteins in nematodes and human cancer cell lines, suggesting potential for cancer therapy.
population_specificity: Human epithelial cancer cells (Calu-3) and nematodes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of chemically synthesized gold nanoparticles (GNPs) and flaxseed-green-synthesized gold nanoparticles (Fs-GNPs) conjugated with AS1411 aptamer as targeted therapeutic systems for breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found successful conjugation of AS1411 aptamer with both GNPs and Fs-GNPs, with Fs-GNPs showing higher inhibitory efficacy against breast cancer cells in cytotoxicity assessments. Characterization confirmed the nanoparticles' size, charge, and morphology, validating the conjugation process.
population_specificity: Breast cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cholesterol-lowering efficacy of flaxseed as an alternative treatment for hypercholesterolemia compared to statins and other dietary supplements.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed may effectively reduce cholesterol levels, though the specific value varied across studies. It was noted as having a beneficial impact on cholesterol levels with consistent usage.
population_specificity: Patients with hypercholesterolemia (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to definitively understand the effect of flaxseed supplementation on apolipoproteins in adults by analyzing randomized clinical trials.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced apo-BI levels, with a standardized mean difference of -0.57 (95% CI: -0.95, -0.19, p = 0.003), indicating a beneficial effect on apolipoproteins.
population_specificity: Adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the challenges of diagnosing seed allergies, including flaxseed, and discuss the extrapolation of oral immunotherapy (OIT) protocols to seeds like sesame and sunflower.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that flaxseed allergy has been reported but does not provide specific findings about its effects or outcomes. The focus is on sunflower seed OIT in a clinical case.
population_specificity: Not specified for flaxseed; general discussion on seed allergies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the potential of various phytochemicals, including flaxseed oil, in targeting cellular signaling pathways to reduce intestinal inflammation in IBD.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that flaxseed oil, among other natural compounds, may help reduce intestinal inflammation by modulating antioxidant and anti-inflammatory pathways, though specific results for flaxseed are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of IBD patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of flaxseed meal (as a placebo) compared to KGM-enriched candy on appetite, anthropometric data, and biochemical markers in overweight individuals.
results_summary: The study did not report specific results for flaxseed meal, as it was used as a placebo control; the primary focus was on KGM's effects.
population_specificity: Overweight individuals aged 18-45 years.
effective_dosage: 250 mg of flaxseed meal per candy, 2 candies per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of flaxseed or its oil supplementation on metabolic, hormonal, and anthropometric parameters in women with PCOS.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation showed potential to improve metabolic, hormonal, and anthropometric parameters in women with PCOS, but the scarcity of high-quality studies necessitates further research for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of flaxseed supplementation on cardiometabolic parameters in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced hemoglobin A1c (HbA1c) in T2DM patients, particularly those with poorly controlled blood sugar, but had no significant effects on body weight, BMI, blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, insulin resistance, or most lipid parameters. Subgroup analyses showed benefits in specific populations, such as improved lipid profiles with whole flaxseed.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the inhibitory effects of plants, including flaxseed, on platelet aggregation in healthy individuals as primary prevention for atherothrombotic events.
results_summary: Among the 10 plants evaluated, nine, including flaxseed, demonstrated inhibitory effects on platelet aggregation, suggesting potential benefits in reducing atherothrombotic risk. The mechanisms behind these effects were also discussed.
population_specificity: Healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acute effects of raw flaxseed consumption on the 2-hour postprandial glycemic response in men with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study found that consuming 15 g of ground raw golden flaxseed before breakfast reduced the peak glucose rise by 17% and the 2-hour AUC glycemic response by 24%, with no differences in palatability or taste parameters compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Nineteen men with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
effective_dosage: 15 g of ground raw golden flaxseed, consumed once before breakfast.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flaxseed oil could positively regulate PPAR-γ expression in patients with noncommunicable diseases (NCDs).
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed oil may function as a putative PPAR-γ agonist, suggesting potential benefits in lipid and glucose metabolism, inflammation, and oxidative stress. The results were based on a systematic review of placebo-controlled randomized clinical trials.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-85 with chronic diseases such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension, obesity, and cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed oil consumption on blood pressure in patients with metabolic syndrome and related disorders.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant reduction in systolic blood pressure but no significant change in diastolic blood pressure after flaxseed oil consumption. Further investigations were recommended for more reliable evidence.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of flaxseed supplementation on glycemic control variables and insulin resistance in individuals with prediabetes and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found a significant reduction in fasting blood sugar and suggested improvements in glycemic control and insulin resistance, though more RCTs are needed to confirm optimal doses and methods of supplementation.
population_specificity: Individuals with prediabetes and type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of flaxseed lignan supplementation (SDG) on host gene expression and inflammatory status, stratified by microbial metabolism of SDG into enterolignans.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed lignan supplementation led to differential gene expression in fecal exfoliated cells, with high-ENL excreters showing 165 DE genes and low-ENL excreters showing 1450 DE genes. Enhanced conversion of flaxseed lignan to ENL was associated with a suppressed inflammatory status, mediated by common upstream regulators like CD3, IFNG, IGF1, and TNFRSF1A.
population_specificity: 42 men and women

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of omega-3 (flaxseed oil) in the medical management of oral submucous fibrosis (OSMF) when used alongside intralesional injections.
results_summary: The study found that flaxseed oil (omega-3) significantly improved clinical parameters (inter-incisal distance, tongue protrusion, cheek flexibility) after 3 months and reduced burning sensation after just one month compared to placebo, with no reported side effects.
population_specificity: 48 clinically confirmed patients with OSMF (grade II and III).
effective_dosage: 1g of flaxseed oil (omega-3) three times daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of brown and golden flaxseeds on lipid profile, oxidative stress, intestinal permeability, endotoxemia, and fasting glycaemia in perimenopausal overweight women.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in intestinal permeability in the flaxseed groups, as indicated by a smaller delta in the lactulose/mannitol ratio. Other outcomes (lipid profile, oxidative stress, endotoxemia, fasting glycaemia) were not detailed in the provided abstract.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal overweight women
effective_dosage: 40 g daily of either brown or golden flaxseed

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of flaxseed and other herbal bioactive compounds on reducing serum TNF-α levels in overweight or obese individuals.
results_summary: Flaxseed was among the plants with promising effects on reducing TNF-α concentration, though results varied across different herbal products. The abstract suggests herbal medicines, including flaxseed, may help mitigate inflammation-related markers in obesity.
population_specificity: Subjects with overweight or obesity

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefit and tolerability of two dosages of a proprietary flaxseed mucilage (IQP-LU-104) in reducing body weight in overweight and moderately obese individuals.
results_summary: The study found that both high and low doses of IQP-LU-104 significantly reduced body weight, BMI, waist and hip circumferences, and body fat mass compared to placebo, with the high dose showing greater efficacy. Adverse events were mild and unrelated to the supplement.
population_specificity: Overweight and moderately obese individuals (BMI 25-<35 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: 1 sachet (high or low dose) before or with main meals twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of functional foods, including flaxseed, in health benefits and disease prevention or treatment.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about flaxseed's effects.
population_specificity: Not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed on lipid profiles in both healthy and dyslipidemic subjects.
results_summary: Flaxseed significantly improved total cholesterol (TC), low-density lipoprotein (LDL-C), and triglycerides (TG) in dyslipidemic patients, while increasing HDL-C in healthy individuals. No significant changes in HDL-C were observed in dyslipidemic subjects.
population_specificity: Healthy and dyslipidemic subjects (total of 1107 participants across 14 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of flaxseed oil (ALA) and fish oil (DHA) on plasma oxylipins and metabolic health markers in women with obesity.
results_summary: Flaxseed oil did not alter plasma oxylipins but reduced ATP-linked oxygen consumption and increased spare respiratory capacity in monocytes, countering LPS-induced shifts. It did not affect inflammatory markers.
population_specificity: Women aged 20-51 with a BMI of 30-51 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of flaxseed consumption on serum lipids, adiponectin, leptin, and anthropometric indices in overweight or obese women.
results_summary: Flaxseed consumption significantly reduced waist circumference and waist-to-hip ratio and increased adiponectin levels, but did not meaningfully affect serum lipid levels.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese women (n=60)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of flaxseed supplementation on BMI, blood pressure, and total cholesterol levels in hypertensive patients.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, BMI, and total cholesterol levels, with the 30g dose showing the most pronounced effects compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Hypertensive patients aged 35-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the validity of dietary supplementation with SDG from flaxseeds in cancer prevention and during chemotherapy, as well as assess regulatory perspectives on flaxseed supplementation.
results_summary: The study highlights flaxseed's potential benefits, including its high fiber content reducing colorectal cancer risk, anti-inflammatory properties from ALA, and anticancer significance attributed to SDG. Regulatory views from EFSA and FDA on flaxseed supplementation were also presented.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on cancer prevention and chemotherapy patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the metabolic profiling of flaxseed-derived lignans in normal and malignant mammary tissues of breast cancer patients and assess their anticancer activity.
results_summary: The study detected phase-II metabolites of flaxseed in tissues, blood, and urine, with total metabolite concentrations reaching measurable levels. Anticancer activity was tested in BC cell lines, but specific efficacy results for flaxseed alone were not highlighted.
population_specificity: Newly-diagnosed breast cancer patients (n = 26 in the intervention group, n = 13 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 3 capsules/day (flaxseed extract included in a blend with turmeric, red clover, and resveratrol; 296.4 mg phenolics/capsule).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine associations between gut microbiota and lignan metabolism from flaxseed consumption and whether these associations differ by ethnicity.
results_summary: The study found a significant difference in gut microbiota composition (beta diversity) after flaxseed intervention, suggesting an impact on microbial communities, with potential variations by ethnicity.
population_specificity: 252 healthy, postmenopausal women of African ancestry (AA) and European ancestry (EA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of flaxseed supplementation in improving metabolic syndrome-related parameters in patients with mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly improved insulin sensitivity, lipid profiles, inflammatory markers (TNF-α, CRP), and disease activity (SCCAI score), but did not affect body weight, BMI, waist circumference, or blood pressure.
population_specificity: 70 patients with mild-to-moderate ulcerative colitis (64 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of non-pharmacologic approaches, including flaxseed, for treating functional constipation, particularly in pediatric populations.
results_summary: The abstract indicates that flaxseed has supportive studies in adults but lacks robust evidence in pediatric populations. It is implied to be safe with no significant side effects mentioned, though efficacy data is limited.
population_specificity: Primarily adults (pediatric evidence is lacking or flawed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of grounded flaxseed (GF) and flaxseed oil (FO) on clinical biomarkers, quality of life, and disease activity in patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: GF and FO significantly reduced hs-CRP and Mayo scores while improving quality of life in UC patients. FO also increased IL-10 concentration, but no significant change was observed in TLR4 mRNA expression.
population_specificity: 90 patients with ulcerative colitis (75 completed the study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of flaxseed oil supplementation on biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly reduced interleukin 6 (IL-6) and malondialdehyde (MDA) levels while increasing total antioxidant capacity (TAC), but did not affect other biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS) and related disorders.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of plant-derived n3-PUFAs, particularly from flaxseed, on lipid profiles and cardiometabolic markers.
results_summary: Flaxseed, a rich source of ALA, demonstrated strong scientific rationale for improving cardiovascular metabolism, alongside beneficial nutrients like fiber, potassium, magnesium, and polyphenols. Its ALA content significantly outperforms rapeseed and soybean oils.
population_specificity: Not specified (general applicability implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of flaxseed meal (FM) supplemented biscuits on body weight, body composition, and blood lipids in overweight and obese participants.
results_summary: The study found that FM-supplemented biscuits significantly reduced body weight, BMI, and TG levels compared to the control group, and also lowered serum IL-6 concentrations.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults aged 18-36 years.
effective_dosage: Approximately 100 g of FM-supplemented biscuits per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether consuming flaxseed oil-enriched chicken meat and eggs could increase n-3 PUFA intake and improve fatty acid profiles in healthy volunteers.
results_summary: The study found that consuming omega-3 enriched meat and eggs significantly increased n-3 PUFA content in erythrocytes but had no effect on body composition, blood lipids, coagulation parameters, or inflammation markers.
population_specificity: 14 healthy volunteers (with a control group of 14).
effective_dosage: 480 g of meat and 4 eggs (228 g netto) per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-cancer effects of flaxseed lignans (SDG, END, and ENL) on acute myeloid leukemia (AML) cells in vitro and explore the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: ENL showed significant selective dose- and time-dependent cytotoxic effects on AML cell lines (KG-1 and Monomac-1) but not on normal cells, inducing apoptosis via the intrinsic pathway, DNA fragmentation, and increased ROS production.
population_specificity: In vitro study using AML cell lines (KG-1 and Monomac-1) and a normal lymphoblastic cell line.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether omega-3 fatty acids from flaxseed oil (1000 mg/day) improved the healing of foot ulcers in people with diabetes compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no clear evidence that flaxseed oil supplementation improved ulcer healing or dimensions compared to placebo, with very low certainty of evidence due to risks of bias, indirectness, and imprecision.
population_specificity: People with diabetes suffering from foot ulcers.
effective_dosage: 1000 mg/day omega-3 fatty acids from flaxseed oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the clinical effects of flaxseed, alone and in combination with hesperidin, on metabolic profiles, inflammation, and hepatic steatosis in patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: Flaxseed supplementation significantly improved glucose homeostasis, reduced insulin resistance, and decreased hepatic steatosis in NAFLD patients, with synergistic effects observed when combined with hesperidin.
population_specificity: Patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of flaxseed lignan extract on plasma bile acid concentrations and explore associations with enterolactone (ENL) excretion and bacterial metabolism.
results_summary: The study found no significant intervention effects on bile acid concentrations overall or when stratified by ENL excretion. However, cross-sectional analysis identified associations between five secondary bile acids and ENL excretion, suggesting overlap in bacterial metabolism of bile acids and lignans.
population_specificity: 46 healthy men and women aged 20-45 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine adherence to a gluten-free diet among celiac disease patients in Paraguay and identify risk factors for non-adherence.
results_summary: The study found that 59% of adults and 73% of children/adolescents adhered to the gluten-free diet, with longer diagnosis duration and younger age being significant factors for adherence.
population_specificity: Celiac disease patients in Paraguay (371 respondents: 322 adults, 49 children/adolescents; 85% female).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a gluten-free diet on IBS symptoms and gut microenvironment, and identify predictors of response to the diet in IBS patients.
results_summary: A gluten-free diet improved IBS symptoms and reduced loose stools, with distinct metabolite profiles observed between responders and non-responders. The response to the diet could be predicted by pre-intervention metabolite profiles.
population_specificity: 20 IBS patients and 18 healthy controls.
effective_dosage: 14 g/day of gluten or rice flour powder sprinkled over meals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the impact of a gluten-free diet (GFD) on gut microbiota and metabolomics in celiac disease (CD) patients, and assess potential biomarkers for non-invasive CD diagnosis.
results_summary: The study found that both CD and GFD significantly alter gut microbiota composition and metabolite production, but the metabolomic signature remains contradictory and understudied. It suggests potential biomarkers for CD diagnosis but highlights inconsistencies in current research.
population_specificity: Individuals with celiac disease (CD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess eating competence and factors related to adherence to a gluten-free diet among Brazilian adults with gluten-related disorders.
results_summary: The study found that individuals who strictly adhered to a gluten-free diet had higher eating competence scores, with factors like higher socioeconomic status, education, and home preparation of gluten-free foods contributing to better adherence and satisfaction. Younger individuals (<40 years) had lower eating competence scores, and the main reported difficulty was the high cost of gluten-free foods.
population_specificity: Brazilian adults with gluten-related disorders, predominantly female, aged 40 or older, with higher income and education levels.
study_duration: Not specified (cross-sectional survey conducted over ~1.5 months)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess changes in microbiota composition during a gluten-free diet (GFD) in coeliac disease (CD) patients compared to healthy individuals and untreated CD patients.
results_summary: The study found that a GFD did not fully restore commensal microorganism abundance but was associated with greater abundance of beneficial bacteria and lower presence of pathogenic bacteria linked to worsening CD symptoms. Bifidobacterium was less abundant in CD patients on GFD, while Bacteroides was more numerous, and Staphylococcaceae prevailed in untreated CD patients.
population_specificity: 212 patients with CD on GFD, compared to 174 healthy individuals and 176 untreated CD patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a gluten-free diet influences the effect of vitamin D treatment on thyroid autoimmunity and function in young women with Hashimoto's thyroiditis.
results_summary: The study found that a gluten-free diet reduced the beneficial effects of exogenous vitamin D on thyroid antibody titers and thyroid function in women with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, compared to those not following dietary restrictions. Vitamin D's positive effects were less pronounced in the gluten-free group.
population_specificity: Euthyroid premenopausal women with Hashimoto's thyroiditis, including 31 women with non-celiac gluten sensitivity on a gluten-free diet and 31 unaffected sisters without dietary intervention.
interactions: Gluten-free diet impaired the beneficial effects of exogenous vitamin D.
